gonads. The sex glands of`the male are grayish white; those of the
female are maroon-red. After rinsing out the contents of the cavity
with fresh sea-water, place the males upside down in a watch 
to allow the sperm to run out through the genital pore. This is
*dry* sperm. Pick the ovaries out of the shell and place in a finger
bowl full of sea-water. After approximately five minutes strain
through cheese cloth and then wash the gametes as described above
for the starfish. The gametes are now ready to use in your observa-
tions. All should be prepared fresh unless otherwise indicated.
l. of the gametes. e. Q. Q.
The Ovum: Mount freshly shed eggs in a little sea~water and
observe the appearance of the egg. Are all the eggs of the same
size? Are they all in the same stage of development? Cad you see
the nucleus? Does the protoplasm of which the egg is composed
appear homogeneous in all regions? Are there any cytoplasmic inclu>>
sions? Can you see any pigment within the eggs? ls there more than
one hind? Is there any evidence of differentiated structure within
the cytoplasm? Do you see any polar bodies? How many? Do you see
any evidence of jelly around the egg? New mount some eggs in a
small amount of sea-water containing a heavy suspension of india ink.
What structures are new visible that you did not see before? Look
at a number of eggs and see if you can find the micropyle. This
may be seen as a conical depression in the jelly surrounding some
of the eggs. ls the jelly coat always the same thickness? Make
drawings to illustrate the points observed and compare the different
eggs studied. Do mature eggs of the different forms differ in size?
The sperm: Place a very small amount of the dry sperm in a drop
of sea-water on a slide. A sufficient number will be carried on the
end of a pair of forceps dipped in the ?dry' sperm preparation, Try
to observe the form of the sperm and their motility. For the latter'
determination use sea-water with india ink suspension. A demonstra-
tion of spemn under dark field illumination will be made.
2. Nahiration of the ovum. Q. Q. Q.
When shed under normal conditions, the eggs of all three of the
animals studied are ready for fertilization. When removed from the
ovaries in the laboratory some of the ova are not mature. Examine
eggs from each of the forms. Those of the starfish are best for the
study of the maturation process. Place some eggs from a freshly pre-
pared culture on a slide and note the condition of the nucleus in
several. Select oocytes with.germinal vesicle intact and observe
them over a period of from one and one~half hours to two hours, Re~
cord the changes observed by means of sketches. he sure the illumina
tion employed is correct in order that you may trace the formation
of the polar bodies, .Do you find any immature eggs in cultures from
Echinarachnius and Arbacia? Sketch. When the eggs are mature they
may be fertilized.
5. Fertilization. Q. Q.
In order to avoid pathological polyspermy in the eggs studied
a dilute sperm suspension should be used in making the inseminations.
This may be assured by the following method. Add one drop of *dry*
sperm to 25 cc. of sea~water. To a mass of eggs in approximately
50 occ. of sea-water. add 6 to 7 drops of this suspension. "his con~
